citation.article-title: Reclassification of Treponema hyodysenteriae and Treponema innocens in a new genus, Serpula gen. nov., as Serpula hyodysenteriae comb. nov. and Serpula innocens comb. nov.

p.s: Description of Serpula Stanton, Jensen, Casey, Tordoff, Dewhirst, and Paster gen. nov.
Serpula (Ser'pu.la. L. fem. n. Serpula, a little serpent [53])
Unless otherwise indicated, the information below was taken from previous descriptions of T. hyodysenteriae and T. innocens (11, 23, 42).
Helical cells with loose, regular coils, 7 to 9 μm by 0.3 to 0.4 μm.
Gram reaction negative.

Typical spirochete ultrastructure consisting of outer sheath, protoplasmic cylinder bounded by a cytoplasmic membrane, and endoflagella inserted at each end of a protoplasmic cylinder and lying between the outer sheath and the protoplasmic cylinder.
Eight or nine flagella are inserted at each end of a cell.
Motile; flexing and creeping at 22°C; translational movement at 37 to 42°C.
Host associated.
Isolated from intestinal contents and feces of swine and other mammals.
One species, Serpula hyodysenteriae, is enteropathogenic for swine.
Chemoorganotrophic.
Uses soluble sugars for growth.
Weakly fermentative.
Produces acetate, butyrate, H2, and CO2 from glucose.
Does not reduce nitrate.
Negative for lipase and lecithinase.
Does not grow in media containing 1% glycine.
Grows anaerobically in Trypticase soy or brain heart infusion broth containing 10% fetal calf, calf, or rabbit serum.
Growth occurs at 36 to 42°C.
Does not grow at 25 and 30°C.
Surface colonies on Trypticase soy blood agar plates are visible after 48 to 96 h of incubation at 38°C.
Colonies are 0.5 to 3 mm in diameter, flat, translucent, and, depending on the species, weakly or strongly beta-hemolytic.

Selective culture media for isolating Serpula hyodysenteriae and Serpula innocens from intestinal contents contain spectinomycin (43) or a combination of spectinomycin, colistin, vancomycin, rifampin, and spiramycin (26).
At specific base locations in the 16s rRNA, Serpula species contain spirochete signature nucleotides (38, 52; this study).
The genus Serpula is differentiated from other spirochete genera on the basis of DNA homology or 16s rRNA sequence similarity data.

A 16s rRNA signature region for three strains of Serpula hyodysenteriae and two strains of Serpula innocens has the following sequence: 5’-CGGRAACGCCUCGGAUACUGURAGUC-3’, where R is A or G (this study).
This sequence corresponds to E. coli 16s rRNA base positions 625 to 650 (3).
The G+C contents of the DNAs of the strains tested are 25 to 26 mol%.
The type species is Serpula hyodysenteriae.
